results.title: Basketball fundamentals for boys
results.brief_description: Branch McCracken, Indiana basketball coach and his Hoosier team demonstrate the fundamentals of shooting, passing, dribbling, defensive and offensive footwork. No other credits available.

results.title: Basketball for girls [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: This film shows basketball as a game of skill, based on cooperative team play. It is presented in eleven sequences to enable discussion and clarification of the points in each. A short description of the game follows, then particular aspects are fully explained and demonstrated. Common faults are shown and the necessity for regular practice of court system is stressed.

results.title: Basketball diaries
results.creator_credit: Island Pictures, Liz Heller and Scott Kalvert
results.brief_description: ‘The Basketball Diaries’ is a horrowing growing-up story based on the true-life exploits of poet and musician Jim Carroll. Jim begins as a high-school basketball star at a Catholic high school where he experiments with drugs and is physically abused by his teachers. When his best friend dies of leukemia, Jim’s life suddenly becomes much more than adolescent angst, with him making the dark descent into the hell of heroin addiction and hustling. Jim’s poetry is the only thing he has left when he is found, literally on the street, by a tough ex-junkie, who undertakes his rehabilitation. Cast include: Leonardo Di Caprio, Bruno Kirby, Juliette Lewis and Ernie Hudson.

results.title: Basketball clinic
results.creator_credit: Seven Network Limited (Australia), Dick Jones and Brendan McKenna
results.brief_description: This film shows a judicious selection of situations from games of basketball played in Melbourne, using stills, action replays, etc to provide excellent illustrations of playing areas, fouls, and shooting and rebounding skills. It is recommended for use with students who have basic proficiency in basketball.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Seven Network Limited (Australia), Dick Jones and Brendan McKenna

results.title: Basketball arcade cabinet
results.brief_description: Before NBA Jam, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released just in time for the arcade heyday of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball controller and a 45-degree angled side view.

constellations_primary.name: Atari’s Basketball
constellations_primary.description: Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, Atari’s Basketball was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. This set the standard for basketball games that followed.

results.description: Before NBA Jam and the NBA 2K basketball series, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.
description_for_label: Before NBA Jam and the NBA 2K basketball series, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.

results.title: Basket case
results.creator_credit: Analysis Films, Edgar Levins and Frank Henenlotter
results.brief_description: Hilarious, cult, low-budget, highly eccentric slasher horror flick from Frank Henenlotter is about two Siamese twins, reluctantly separated in adolescence by merciless doctors. Seeking revenge, the two (one a full bodied man, and the other a head in a basket) set up in a seedy New York hotel, where they encounter an array of fringe dwellers. Minimal and basic special effects do not detract from the gruesome fun of seeing a mutant, enraged head on the rampage. Followed by two sequels in the 1990s.

results.title: Basilisk stare
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Mis Kamieniak and Chryss Carr
results.brief_description:
A psychosexual drama which launches the viewer into the inner-space of the male psyche in order to depict the way the modern male constructs sex. The film excites and disturbs the viewer with the use of a split screen, which allows for the pitching of two images against each other in order to create a sense of both excitement and voyeuristic curiosity.
Cast includes David Wenham, Amy Pedersen and Jared Turner
